The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified. Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined all function parameters: cls (void *), pos (uint64_t), buf (char *), and max (size_t). There are no statements that assign to any of these parameter variables (no occurrences of cls = ..., pos = ..., buf = ..., or max = ...). The only pointer-to-object operations are: assigning the parameter value to a local pointer (DIR *dir = cls;), calling readdir(dir) which may modify the DIR object referred to by cls, and calling snprintf(buf, ...) which writes to the object pointed to by buf. Per MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8, modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted, but modifying the pointer parameter itself is not. The local assignment DIR *dir = cls does not modify the parameter; it merely copies its value. The explicit discard (void) pos; does not modify pos. Therefore no code fragments modify function parameters themselves and no further investigation under Rule 17.8 is required.
